ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to think about information using abstract frameworks and combining elements from philosophy, anthropology, and computer science. The guiding principle of the course is the relationship between the immediate and the mediate. Specifically, the relationships between meaning and information, between interpretation and computation, and between interaction and infrastructure.

This course was excellend. I have studied semiotics with other professors at Yale and Prof. Kockelman elucidated concepts in ways other professors simply could not. The course expanded my knowledge with respect to information systems. The texts selected by the professor were among the most interesting I have ever read. Prof. Kockelman's subsequent explanations of these texts were just as insightful. I am really grateful to have been in this course.
I have gained new perspective on digital and computational mediation of meaning. How information can be perceived, distracted, and sometimes mediated through a secondary interaction.
This course provides a fascinating survey of major themes in the field, and took several unexpected turns that all fed back into each other usefully.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is unique in it's multidisciplinary approach to the material, effectively combining ideas from philosophy, anthropology, and computer science. The lectures are extremely engaging and often left me pondering the material throughout the week and making connections to other courses. At times the material can feel esoteric, but professor Kockelman makes the nature of the material clear from the beginning. Another weakness of the course is that it is effectively a lecture, so just set your expectations.
Prof Kockelman is an excellent lecturer. The course was a high point of my week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, whether they have a background in anthropology or not. The course material is so broad that anyone will get something out of it and have ideas to contribute. The course will also have you thinking about the material outside the class. The term paper is very open ended and you can write about something you're really interested in.
Yes, but only to students who have some background in semiotics, in particular a preliminary understanding of Peirce.
I would highly recommend this course to any student in the school of art
Absolutely would recommend. I think everyone should take this course.
